title: Sinner Cruises to ATP Finals Victory
description: Jannik Sinner is the 2024 Nitto ATP finals champion after comfortably defeating Taylor Fritz 6-4 6-4 in Sundayâ€™s final, becoming the first player from his country to win the tournament in its 55-year history. The Italian emerges as the undefeated champion (without even dropping a set) and wins $4,881,100 in prize money, making it a â€¦
author: Jonathan
excerpt: Jannik Sinner is the 2024 Nitto ATP finals champion after comfortably defeating Taylor Fritz 6-4 6-4 in Sunday's final, becoming the first player from his country to win the tournament in its 55-year
text: Jannik Sinner is the 2024 Nitto ATP finals champion after comfortably defeating Taylor Fritz 6-4 6-4 in Sundayâ€™s final, becoming the first player from his country to win the tournament in its 55-year history. The Italian emerges as the undefeated champion (without even dropping a set) and wins $4,881,100 in prize money, making it a successful last few months for the bank balance after the $6 million he won at the Six Kings Slam. Sinner was dominant throughout, playing his brand of precision tennis and winning 83% of points behind his first serve, which left Fritz with no real chance to find a chink in his armour. Fritz is the first Yank since James Blake back in 2006 to make the finals, and while he leaves Turin disappointed, heâ€™s the top American right now and has had one of his best seasons on tour. As a result, he will rise to a career-high No. 4 in the ATP Rankings on Monday. Itâ€™s amazing, itâ€™s my first title in Italy and it means so much to me. Itâ€™s something very special. I just tried to understand what works best for each opponent, trying to play my best possible tennis. That was the key. It was a very high level tournament from my side. At times, I couldnâ€™t have played better, so I am very happy. Sinner on his maiden ATP Finals win. 2024 ATP Finals Result Winner Loser Scoreline Jannik Sinner (1) Taylor Fritz (5) 6-4 6-4 Match Stats Â  Jannik Sinner Taylor Fritz Aces 14 8 Double Faults 0 2 1st Serve Percentage 71% 75% 1st Serve Points Won 83% (33/40) 70% (32/46) 2nd Serve Points Won 63% (10/16) 60% (9/15) Break Points Saved 100% (1/1) 67% (4/6) 1st Return Points Won 30% (14/46) 18% (7/40) 2nd Return Points Won 40% (6/15) 38% (6/16) Break Points Converted 33% (2/6) 0% (0/1) Winners 28 20 Unforced Errors 17 21 Net Points Won 67% (8/12) 75% (9/12) Service Points Won 77% (43/56) 67% (41/61) Return Points Won 33% (20/61) 23% (13/56) Total Points Won 54% (63/117) 46% (54/117) Service Games Won 100% (10/10) 80% (8/10) Return Games Won 20% (2/10) 0% (0/10) Total Games Won 60% (12/20) 40% (8/20) Highlights Thoughts on the Final It was an expected win for Sinner here, but I thought Fritz played decently enough â€“ landing 70% of first serves, winning 70% behind it and 60% behind his second serve. You donâ€™t lose too many matches with numbers like that, but Sinner is just too solid and disciplined to be troubled by what Fritz can offer.Â  With his relentless ball-striking, the Italian always draws his opponent into making untimely errors, and thatâ€™s what happened in the final; he broke in the seventh game of the first set and the fifth game of the second. The only real trouble he faced was saving a sole break point when serving out the opener. Thereâ€™s little Fritz can do to make him uncomfortable, so I canâ€™t see how he can get on top from the baseline. Even when Sinner is in a more defensive position, he can maintain the type of ball speed typically restricted to when you can plant your feet.Â  Fritz can at least find some positives in playing much better than the US Open final, in which he served poorly. Tonight, his numbers were solid. He just ran into a player whoâ€™s exceptionally hard to beat on hard courts right now, and thereâ€™s likely only Djokovic and Alcaraz who can do it. As for Sinner, he finishes the season with eight titles, including 2 Grand Slams and a 92.1% win rate (70-6 wins/losses). ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º Australian Open ğŸ† ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± Rotterdam ğŸ† ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ Miami ğŸ† ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª Halle ğŸ† ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ Cincinnati ğŸ† ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ US Open ğŸ† ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ Shanghai ğŸ† ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹ ATP FinalsğŸ† So, while it was an excellent year for him in terms of titles and money earned, it would be amiss not to mention the two failed doping tests. Whatever anyone says, e.g. people like Angelo Binaghi, President of the Italian Tennis Federation, who claims, â€œApart from a few imbeciles, people worldwide understand what happened. Thereâ€™s no doubt that Sinner is one of the cleanest and most honest athletes in world sport.â€ there are some significant question marks around the case that need answering. WADA thinks so, too, and it doesnâ€™t help when people like Binaghi call anyone asking questions an imbecile.Â  Remember, you donâ€™t have to go too far back to when those in positions of â€œauthorityâ€ branded people imbeciles for talking about a lab leak. We all know how that one turned out, and Iâ€™d imagine there are plenty of internal emails that would shed some light on this whole debacle. Hopefully, we get to learn more. Did you enjoy the 2024 ATP Finals? Let me know in the comments. Follow Us Editor of Perfect Tennis and a big fan of Roger Federer, I've spent countless hours watching and analysing his matches. html:
Jannik Sinner is the 2024 Nitto ATP finals champion after comfortably defeating Taylor Fritz 6-4 6-4 in Sundayâ€™s final, becoming the first player from his country to win the tournament in its 55-year history.

The Italian emerges as the undefeated champion (without even dropping a set) and wins $4,881,100 in prize money, making it a successful last few months for the bank balance after the $6 million he won at the Six Kings Slam.

Sinner was dominant throughout, playing his brand of precision tennis and winning 83% of points behind his first serve, which left Fritz with no real chance to find a chink in his armour.

Fritz is the first Yank since James Blake back in 2006 to make the finals, and while he leaves Turin disappointed, heâ€™s the top American right now and has had one of his best seasons on tour. As a result, he will rise to a career-high No. 4 in the ATP Rankings on Monday.

Itâ€™s amazing, itâ€™s my first title in Italy and it means so much to me. Itâ€™s something very special. I just tried to understand what works best for each opponent, trying to play my best possible tennis. That was the key. It was a very high level tournament from my side. At times, I couldnâ€™t have played better, so I am very happy. Sinner on his maiden ATP Finals win.

2024 ATP Finals Result

Winner Loser Scoreline
Jannik Sinner (1) Taylor Fritz (5) 6-4 6-4

Match Stats

Â  Jannik Sinner Taylor Fritz
Aces 14 8
Double Faults 0 2
1st Serve Percentage 71% 75%
1st Serve Points Won 83% (33/40) 70% (32/46)
2nd Serve Points Won 63% (10/16) 60% (9/15)
Break Points Saved 100% (1/1) 67% (4/6)
1st Return Points Won 30% (14/46) 18% (7/40)
2nd Return Points Won 40% (6/15) 38% (6/16)
Break Points Converted 33% (2/6) 0% (0/1)
Winners 28 20
Unforced Errors 17 21
Net Points Won 67% (8/12) 75% (9/12)
Service Points Won 77% (43/56) 67% (41/61)
Return Points Won 33% (20/61) 23% (13/56)
Total Points Won 54% (63/117) 46% (54/117)
Service Games Won 100% (10/10) 80% (8/10)
Return Games Won 20% (2/10) 0% (0/10)
Total Games Won 60% (12/20) 40% (8/20)

Highlights

Thoughts on the Final

It was an expected win for Sinner here, but I thought Fritz played decently enough â€“ landing 70% of first serves, winning 70% behind it and 60% behind his second serve.

You donâ€™t lose too many matches with numbers like that, but Sinner is just too solid and disciplined to be troubled by what Fritz can offer.Â 

With his relentless ball-striking, the Italian always draws his opponent into making untimely errors, and thatâ€™s what happened in the final; he broke in the seventh game of the first set and the fifth game of the second. The only real trouble he faced was saving a sole break point when serving out the opener.

Thereâ€™s little Fritz can do to make him uncomfortable, so I canâ€™t see how he can get on top from the baseline.

Even when Sinner is in a more defensive position, he can maintain the type of ball speed typically restricted to when you can plant your feet.Â 

Fritz can at least find some positives in playing much better than the US Open final, in which he served poorly.

Tonight, his numbers were solid. He just ran into a player whoâ€™s exceptionally hard to beat on hard courts right now, and thereâ€™s likely only Djokovic and Alcaraz who can do it.

As for Sinner, he finishes the season with eight titles, including 2 Grand Slams and a 92.1% win rate (70-6 wins/losses).

So, while it was an excellent year for him in terms of titles and money earned, it would be amiss not to mention the two failed doping tests.

Whatever anyone says, e.g. people like Angelo Binaghi, President of the Italian Tennis Federation, who claims, â€œApart from a few imbeciles, people worldwide understand what happened. Thereâ€™s no doubt that Sinner is one of the cleanest and most honest athletes in world sport.â€ there are some significant question marks around the case that need answering.

WADA thinks so, too, and it doesnâ€™t help when people like Binaghi call anyone asking questions an imbecile.Â 

Remember, you donâ€™t have to go too far back to when those in positions of â€œauthorityâ€ branded people imbeciles for talking about a lab leak.

We all know how that one turned out, and Iâ€™d imagine there are plenty of internal emails that would shed some light on this whole debacle. Hopefully, we get to learn more.

Did you enjoy the 2024 ATP Finals? Let me know in the comments.
